translated: Sutra on Understanding the Fundamental Nature of Birth and Death
Translated by the Upasaka Zhi Qian of the Wu Dynasty
The Buddha said: If a bhiká¹£u sees dependent origination, it is seeing the Dharma, and having seen the Dharma, it is seeing me.
Then the Venerable ÅšÄriputra said to the bhiká¹£us:
Virtuous ones!
The Buddha said:
'If bhiká¹£us see dependent origination, it is seeing the Dharma, and having seen the Dharma, it is seeing me.'
What does this mean?
This is said to have conditions.
If one sees dependent origination as neither having a life-force nor not having a life-force, it is seeing the Dharma;
Seeing the Dharma as neither having a life-force nor not having a life-force, it is seeing the Buddha.
One should follow this wisdom.
There are two things to see in external dependent origination, and two things to see in internal dependent origination, making four in total.
What are the two things to see in external dependent origination?
They are the bondage of causal characteristics and the bondage of conditional characteristics.
What is the bondage of causal characteristics?
From the seed to the root, from the root to the leaf, from the leaf to the stem, from the stem to the node, from the node to the flower bud, from the flower to the fruit.
This is called the bondage of causal characteristics.
What is meant by the bondage of conditional characteristics?
The earth element, water element, fire element, wind element, and space element, from these conditions, the seed gives rise to that.
The earth supports the seed, the water moistens the seed, the fire ripens the seed, the wind causes the seed to sprout, and space allows the seed to be unobstructed.
In this way, when the time and conditions are right, the seed is able to grow.
The seed does not know that it gives rise to the root, and the root does not know that it comes from the seed;
The root does not know that it gives rise to the leaf, and the leaf does not know that it comes from the root;

The leaf does not know that it gives rise to the stem, and the stem does not know that it comes from the leaf. The node, flower bud, and fruit also do not know that they transform and give rise to each other.
Moreover, the earth does not know that it gives rise to the seed, and the seed also does not know that the earth supports it;
The water also does not know that it moistens the seed, and the seed also does not know that the water moistens it;
Fire, wind, and space are all mutually unaware of each other.
These wise ones, from causes and conditions, attain the right time and conditions for the seeds to grow.
It is not self-made, not made by others, and not born without a cause.
One should see external dependent arising through five things.
What are the five?
First, impermanence; second, non-cessation; third, non-stepping; fourth, the seeds not being lost; fifth, the characteristics not being the same as the old.

When the seeds are destroyed, it is impermanence; when the roots appear, it is non-cessation; when the seeds and roots differ, it is non-stepping; when a small seed produces many fruits, it is non-loss; when the fruits are born like the seeds and roots, it is the characteristics not being the same as the old.
One should know that there are two things to see in internal dependent arising:
The characteristics of causes being bound, and the characteristics of conditions being bound.
What are the characteristics of causes being bound?
Conditioned by ignorance, there are karmic formations;
Conditioned by karmic formations, there is consciousness;
Conditioned by consciousness, there is name-and-form;
Conditioned by name-and-form, there are the six sense bases;
Conditioned by the six sense bases, there is contact;ğŸ”½...
Contact gives rise to feeling;ğŸ”½Feeling gives rise to craving;
Craving gives rise to grasping;ğŸ”½Grasping gives rise to existence;
Existence gives rise to birth;
Birth gives rise to old age, death, sorrow, lamentation, pain, and mental distress.
Thus, this great mass of nothing but suffering comes to be.
They do not understand or know that I create formations, and formations do not know that they exist due to ignorance;
Formations do not know that they create consciousness, and consciousness does not know that it exists due to formations;
Consciousness does not know that it creates name-and-form, and name-and-form does not know that it exists due to consciousness;
The six sense bases, contact, feeling, craving, grasping, existence, birth, and up to old age and death are also mutually unknown.

This is how from ignorance come formations, from formations comes consciousness, from consciousness comes name-and-form, from name-and-form come the six sense bases, contact, feeling, craving, grasping, existence, birth, old age and death, sorrow, lamentation, pain, and mental distress, as explained above.
This is merely the complete existence of the nature of great suffering.
If there is no birth, then there is no old age, death, sorrow, lamentation, pain, dejection, and anguish.
All of you virtuous ones, because of dependent origination, there are dharmas that arise from conditions.

There are dharmas that are dependently originated but not arisen from conditions, there are dharmas that are arisen from conditions but not dependently originated, there are dharmas that are both dependently originated and arisen from conditions, and there are dharmas that are neither dependently originated nor arisen from conditions.
What are the dharmas that are dependently originated but not arisen from conditions?
Taking ignorance as a condition, there are activities;
taking activities as a condition, there is consciousness;

taking consciousness as a condition, there is name-and-form, up to old age, death, sorrow, lamentation, pain, dejection, and anguish, the complete existence of the great mass of suffering, as explained above.
This is called the dharmas that are dependently originated but not arisen from conditions.
What are the dharmas that are arisen from conditions but not dependently originated?
It is like ignorance, activities, consciousness, name-and-form, the six sense bases, contact, feeling, craving, grasping, existence, birth, old age and death.
This is called the dharmas that are arisen from conditions but not dependently originated.
What is meant by the arising of phenomena based on conditions?

If birth arises and abides without ceasing, old age and death arise, and the causes and conditions of birth are proximate, having causes that are proximate, having subtle causes that are proximate, having causes that are true that are proximate, having causes that are thus that are proximate, having causes that are non-different that are proximate, having causes that are non-deluded that are proximate, having causes that are dependently arisen that are proximate, the arising of phenomena based on conditions is thus:
existence, clinging, craving, feeling, contact, the six sense bases, name and form, consciousness, and volitional formations.
These are called the arising of phenomena based on conditions.
What is meant by phenomena that do not arise based on conditions?
It refers to those who have attained the path.
What is meant by ignorance?
It is like the six kinds.
The six kinds of clinging are female and male.
What are the six?
They are the earth element, water element, fire element, wind element, space element, and consciousness element.
The attainment of a body is the earth element;
holding without dispersing is the water element;
Drinking, eating, tasting, chewing, and sleeping are well digested, this is the fire element;
The exhalation and inhalation in the body are the wind element;
What the four great elements cannot hold is the space element;
Following the turning like a pair of arrows squeezed, this is the consciousness element.

Just as that earth element is neither female, nor male, nor human, nor person, nor body, nor body part, nor born from a person, nor young, nor action, nor actor, nor abiding, nor abider, nor wisdom, nor knower, nor sentient being, nor I, nor mine, nor existent, nor nonexistent, nor having a master.
The water, fire, wind, and space elements are also like this.

The seeds of consciousness are neither female, nor male, nor human, nor person, nor body, nor what belongs to the body, nor born of a person, nor youth, nor action, nor without action, nor abiding, nor without an abode, nor wisdom, nor without a knower, nor sentient beings, nor I, nor mine, nor possessed by me, nor without a master.

Thus, it is only from the six kinds that there is a single thought, a combined thought, a thought of a woman, a thought of a man, a deluded thought, a thought of the body, a thought of mastery, a thought of strong mastery, and the acceptance of various kinds, which is why it is not clear.
At that time, it is said to be the nature of delusion, the thoughts of purity, permanence, bliss, and the body, doubt, dislike, and delusion, not the supreme essence.
The Buddha says this is not clear, and it is also defiled by objects, without wisdom, and gives rise to delusion, so it is not clear;
because of delusion, there is activity;
because of knowing objects, there is consciousness;
because of the five natures, there is name-and-form;
because of relying on the faculties of name-and-form, there are the six sense bases;
The three combined are called contact;ğŸ”½The activity of contact is called feeling;ğŸ”½Feeling pleasure is called craving;
Craving expands further is called grasping;
Grasping will lead to future existence is called becoming;
The completion of the five aggregates is called birth;
The ripening of the seeds is called aging;
The closing off of the life faculty is called death;
Distress in the heat is called sorrow;
Deceptive speech is called lamentation;
The combination of the five sense bodies is called the five kinds of suffering;ğŸ”½The combination of the mind and consciousness body is called distress;
Mental toil is called affliction;
Because of existence, there is birth.
Seeing and knowing this, it obstructs the manifestation of this, and is said to be fully endowed with the nature of great suffering.
From this, one experiences misfortune and, due to attachment, gives rise to further existence.
Its beginning cannot be seen, known, or measured.
Moreover, darkness is the meaning of non-illumination;
Accomplishment is the meaning of activity;
Knowledge is the meaning of consciousness;
Dependent on that, mutually relying on each other, is the meaning of name-and-form;
The master is also not exclusive, which is the meaning of the six sense bases;
Again, it is also the meaning of contact when combined;
From the meaning of knowing pain;
Desiring to obtain things, like fire is insatiable, is the meaning of craving;
Grasping is the meaning of receiving;
There will be existence again, which is the meaning of existence;
The five natures are called the meaning of birth;
Maturation is the meaning of old age;
The decline of activities is the meaning of death.

Such explanations are also the characteristics of the twelve links of dependent origination.ğŸ”½Moreover, from ignorance, one approaches the creation of meritorious actions and the creation of sinful actions. This is called the condition of ignorance;
Because of the existence of various activities, one approaches the existence of merit and demerit and has consciousness. This is called the condition of activity and consciousness;
Due to the nature of activity created by consciousness, name and form are fully formed and produced. This is called the condition of consciousness and name and form;
This is the condition of birth and creation, and creation immediately receives. This is called the condition of name and form;
The six sense bases, the meeting of eye-consciousness and contact, is called the condition of the six sense bases and contact;
As with contact, so is the knowledge of pain. This is called the condition of contact and pain;
Those who do not know pain, for the sake of separate practices, follow desire and take it, this is called the condition of desire based on pain;
Following desire and swallowing again, this is called the condition of existence based on desire;
Receiving is the three practices of body, speech, and mind, this is called the condition of existence based on receiving;
Existing practices will again have the completion of birth, this is called the condition of birth based on existence;
The five natures have already been formed, so there is old age and death.
This is the twelve links of dependent origination, turning and revolving, creating the work of the field, consciousness creates the seeds of practice, ignorance creates the opposing practices.
Just as the earth holds the seeds, water prevents the seeds from scattering, fire ripens the seeds, wind causes the seeds to grow, and space provides unobstructed space for the seeds.
Practice creates the work of the field in the same way, desire creates the moistening of practice, but that practice does not know:
'I create the work of the field.'
Desire does not know:
'I moisten the practice.'
Consciousness does not know:
'I am the seed of practice.'
Ignorance does not know:
'I am the one who acts.'
Just as the earth does not know:
'I hold the seeds.'
Water, fire, wind, and space are as explained above.
From the exertion of existence, there will be further completion and birth.
This also has no one who steps from this world, but only the mutual holding of causes and conditions.
It is like a clear and bright mirror, giving rise to the reflection of a face based on internal and external conditions.
The face also does not die here and is born there. From the existence of a face in the mirror, the conditions are not lacking.
It is not dying here and being born there, but there are conditions, and the conditions are not lacking, so there is experience.
Just as fire, when fueled, burns day and night without interruption, yet its flames do not step.
Consciousness is also like this, not bound to the body, coming and going in the five paths.
When there are conditions, there is birth. This dharma has no owner.
It is like the moon, forty-nine yojanas in diameter, but its round shape appears in the water below. It is not because the moon dies there and is born here.
Contemplate birth and death in this way.
This is called the bondage of causal characteristics.
What is the bondage of conditional characteristics?
As the Buddha told Ananda:
'The eye conditions form to give rise to eye consciousness.
The eye does not know:
I create the action of leaning.
Form does not know:
I am the object of consciousness.
Light does not know:
I illuminate consciousness.
Space does not know:
I make consciousness unobstructed.
Consciousness does not know:
I am born here and exist.
The eye, form, light, space, and thought enable eye consciousness to be fully born.
The ear, nose, mouth, body, and mind condition dharmas to give rise to mental consciousness.
The eye does not know:
I create the action of leaning for consciousness.
Dharmas do not know:
I act for consciousness.
The mind does not know:
I make consciousness bright.
Emptiness does not know:
I make consciousness unobstructed.
Consciousness does not know:
I accomplish these causes and conditions.
This, Ä€nanda!

The mind, dharmas, brightness, emptiness, and thought rely on the mind and consciousness to be fully formed, but this is not self-made, not made by others, not made by both, not born without cause, not because of me, not because of others, not without cause.
'One should see internal dependent arising through five things.
What are the five?
Impermanence, non-cessation, non-walking, little action and much retribution, and the appearance is not for the sake of.
It is like the end of death, the body has already decayed and is impermanent;
It gives rise to a body and is not cessation;
Either going the same or going differently, it is non-walking because of the difference in parts;
Little action and much retribution means that the action does not perish.
It is like the retribution of practice, not the family of purpose.
If one sees this dependent origination as neither life nor non-life, it is seeing the Dharma;
Seeing the Dharma as neither life nor non-life is seeing the Four Noble Truths:
Suffering, accumulation, cessation, and the path.
It is like a wise person seeing a master's completed painting, praising the painting's beauty and the master's skill.

Seeing the Four Noble Truths is also like this. The Buddha knows everything and manifests everything. From this, one attains joy and does not leave the Buddha. One attains the true Dharma assembly and the joy of precepts without leaving.
